> that had entered my mind (you biting your tounge here) but about my "not even a link" comment, I wasnt expecting proof of mis post but rather one of your magical links MR Finder, Sir.. closely relating to the topic and one that has all the answers already. (its wouldnt be the first time..) but thanks for reply as usual anyway. Well, in this particular topic the secret ...... [http://www.imdb.com/...es?qt=qt0448742](http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0441773/quotes?qt=qt0448742 "External link") :wink: You posted a question which was based on a couple assumptions (very logical ![:thumbup:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/thumbup.gif), mind you , but unfortunately most of the USB stick manufacturers/sellers are seemingly NOT logic ![:w00t:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/w00t.gif)): * there is a way to indentify the controller inside the USB stick from the actul USB stick brand \<-logic, but proved to be false * all EXACT same model sticks (among the zillion ones each brand sells) contains the same known controller \<- logic, but also proved, at least in some cases, to be false An answer like: > Lexar Jumpdrive (a good one IMHO) is anyway a "vague" one.

We do have reports that many (but cannot say all - as a mattter of fact I would personally exclude this from the certainties) Lexar sticks are (were) compatible with a tool that can be obtained (actually originally coming from Lexar itself) that is a narrowed down version of the controller Manufacturer's Tool and that can flip the bit. Compare with: [http://www.911cd.net...showtopic=21572](http://www.911cd.net/forums//index.php?showtopic=21572 "External link") [http://www.911cd.net...showtopic=21850](http://www.911cd.net/forums//index.php?showtopic=21850 "External link") I have NO way to reliably tell you "Brand X, model Y uses controller Z AND we have for that controller a software W capable of filling the bit". In some cases I cannot even tell you (reliably) "Brand X, Model Y has a VID aaaa/PID bbbb, hence it uses controller Z AND we have for that controller a software W capable of filling the bit" (in some cases you actually need to open the d@mn thingy and read the chip manufacturer/model form the chip itself) Final statement is: Lexar is a "good" brand and in the past we have always managed to flip the bit on any of them we came across, one way or the other ***but*** YMMV. ![:cheers:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/cheers.gif) Wonko
